speaker: D
text: Well, the crypto click actually was a tool for the sustainability click. I guess in December of 2018, you or your viewers may recall that the Amazon was on fire, the forest was burning, and I was wondering, what could I do as an ordinary person to try to help make a difference? And it was really heart wrenching, because I just came to the conclusion that no matter what I wanted to try to do, I couldn't do anything. I had to go about my life. I had to go and basically go to work, take care of the family, move on. So I sort of said, well, how can we solve this climate problem, at least from the plastics perspective? And I actually realized that companies are the ones who are responsible for putting the plastics into the market. So eventually, if we can enable companies to make sure that they recover the plastic, the users or the consumers are the ones who pick the products from companies that have actually proven to be committed to the environment, verifiably so. In that sense, I said, okay, well, then basically what we need to do is we need to provide a tool so that companies can actually make sure they can recover plastics, and we need to make sure that consumers can know that the plastics being recovered, and that way we can connect. And that's when I said, well, let's talk about plastics as a company. And, well, we need to make sure that people know that funds are going to the plastic recovery projects. We need to know that if I'm going to do something, the money is going straight to the pockets of those that are actually doing something about plastic recovery. And that's where crypto walks in. Because ultimately, the underlying reason behind it was, well, if I'm going to make sure that money is being sent to a waste recovery project, I want to know that the waste recovery project, whether theyre in India, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Africa, Latin America or in Asia, are getting the money and the transparency and traceability of a blockchain was the solution to that problem. So crypto was a tool to fight the plastic recovery problem. It was contrary to, at the time, most projects would think, well, I have an idea in crypto, how can I make it fit into the real world? It was, the real world problem is plastics. How can we solve that problem? Oh, the best tool, crypto, the best tool, blockchain.

speaker: C
text: Okay, so from what I've heard that you've told me so far, it's very much the climate problem is still very real. You know, you see the fires out in Europe and you see the californian fires you got, you sort of are aware of the problem very early on and you definitely see the sort of opportunity that, okay, the thing to cut the middle men out of crypto can very much solve that with blockchain technology. So what is plastic and how exactly does it actually work?

speaker: D
text: Well, Elaine, plastics is a marketplace where across the globe, waste recovery projects and waste management companies are able to generate a new source of funding to be able to build out their infrastructure and improve their recycling rates. So the industry hasn't changed in 50 years. The basic revenue model for the waste management industry has always been collecting the waste, sorting it and selling it as a feedstock to the recycling industry. So we came up to them and said, well, wait a minute, you can basically create the data that proves that you've recovered a certain amount of plastic, a certain type of plastic, and that you've actually delivered it to the recycler. So with your data, you can actually create a certificate that will prove that the plastic and the quantity of plastic recovered has not gone into the environment. And what is that data? Well, the invoice, ultimately, for 50 years, the waste management industry has been collecting waste and sorting it and selling it to the recycler. So when they're selling the waste, they're issuing invoices. We said, convert your invoice into an NFT, which is basically a certificate we call a plastic recovery guarantee, and put this plastic recovery guarantee, this NFT up for sale on the plastics marketplace. So who would buy them? Well, companies would buy them for two reasons. The main one is if a company is using, producing or distributing a certain type and amount of plastic. By buying these plastic recovery guarantees, essentially what they're doing is offsetting, is neutralizing their plastic footprint. And the second reason is from a corporate social responsibility exercise. By buying these plastic recovery guarantees, essentially what's happening is that they are funding the recovery of additional plastic because the money is going to the waste recovery project. To do what? To buy new machinery, hire more waste pickers, open up a new geographical area to pick up more plastic waste, deploy medical camps to take care of the medical health of the waste pickers. So it's a measurable impact and all of that by the simple fact of buying this plastic recovery guarantee, which for the most understanding is akin to a plastic credit.

speaker: D
text: Oh, well, first of all, the word grateful is not big enough to represent how we feel about the partnership with FC Barcelona. Ultimately, FC Barcelona obviously complies with their stadium regulation and recovering plastic for every game. They have a huge infrastructure in making sure that they're games are sustainable. But what they wanted to do is they wanted to leverage their brand and say, look, we're a global brand and we want to help recover plastic at a global level. And ultimately we want to empower our community to be part of plastic recovery. So they said, okay, we're going to do a NFT collection and offer this NFT collection to their I community, which will obviously provide them with the uniqueness of the collectible item, the digital collectible access to benefits such as entering a drawing to have one of the shirts, I believe twelve or 13 shirts of the team that have been signed off by all the players, the drawing having access to special benefits, for example, getting tweeted your name on the birthday, a whole series of benefits that they have. But more importantly, linking those nfts to what plastic recovery guarantees related to projects in Chile, Kenya and India. Because what they want to do is they want to recover plastic in those regions and they want fans not only to relate to football club Barcelona, but directly be empowered to recover plastics by buying these nfts. And so after having gone extensive research for web three sustainability partners, we were fortunate enough to be selected by a football club, Barcelona, to actually be the platform upon which they would issue these nfts, these digital collectibles that would be linked to waste recovery projects in the four nations that I've talked about, actually three nations. Four projects in three nations, Chile, Kenya and India. And over the course of the next three years, their commitment is to recover 1 million kilos of plastic. Which I do want to take this moment to say we wanted to establish the price of recovering a kilo at a dollar because what we didn't want were the waste pickers in developing nations to be exposed to the volatility of pricing of waste recovery projects. Ultimately, the carbon credit is endemic for speculation. So what we wanted to say, zero speculation on the actual recovery of plastic. So when a waste picker is collecting a kilo, they're going to get paid their dollar minus our transaction fee, which is 20%, because we are ultimately the verification body. That's our job. We verify according to our own methodology that these projects are allowed to issue these nfts. And then we do the auditing to make sure that the monies generated from the sale of these nfts are going towards what we call roadmaps, buying a machinery, hiring more waste pickers, increasing the salaries of the waste pickers, opening up new geographical areas, deploying medical camps, etcetera. So 80% of the funds goes to the waste recovery project. We know this because it's blockchain. You see the money going straight to the wallet of. And ultimately Barca said, we're going to work with plastics because we know that their plastic recovery guarantee is verifiable and traceable. And that was the great opportunity for them to empower their community, leverage their brand, to actually have an impact on plastic recovery at a global level.

speaker: D
text: Well, I'd like to distinguish different Personas. Right. So you've got brands, you've got companies and communities like football club, Barcelona or like Rosita that say, we want to do something for the environment and we are going to say, how much budget do we have to recover plastic? Or how big is our community, our fan base, so that we can enable to recover plastic. So that's what they would do. And then you've got the actual waste recovery projects that say, well, until plastics arrived, my only source of funding was to actually pick up the plastic and sell it as a physical product. Now I know that I can sell the proof that I've recovered it and put it back into the recycling industry. So essentially I can build my waste recovery process by issuing nfts, so I can fund the growth of my project and fund the growth of plastic recovery. So then they need to, they contact us and then they, what they do is get through a verification process, which we obviously have our own methodology and we measure them in compliance to that methodology. And then the third Persona is the artist. So the artist basically is either on their own saying, I have an art collection, I want to create digital art. And I want to make sure that whoever buys my art is going to pick up and recover plastic, or their art is being acquired by one of the brands so that they can leverage their art to be able to recover plastic. And ultimately, why art? And why do we also talk about the art of recycling? We talk about the art of recycling because the emotional connection that art elicits in people is what we're trying to connect with plastic recovery. So essentially, an emotional connection to a real commitment to the environment is what we're trying to elicit. The power of art is to say, oh, I'm emotionally connected to recovering plastic. Oh, by the way, it's beautiful.
